text:
Sixth Ave, north from Greenwich Ave, showing 8th Street elevated station. Jefferson Market Police Court is seen in left foreground.

About 1890.

Eugene L. Armbruster, Collection.

Christopher Street, west from Greenwich Avenue as viewed from Sixth Avenue (under the "El").

Mr. Sperr reports the following: "John Masefield, as a young man worked in Luke O'Connors Saloon which appears at the left (S.W. corner)."

J. J. Corell
P. L. Sperr

1900

Sixth Avenue side of Jefferson Market.
August 20, 1927.

P.L.Sperr, Photographer.

(2)

Jefferson Market Court and Prison, from S.E. corner of Sixth Avenue at 8th Street.
October 3, 1931.

P.L.Sperr, Photographer.

(1)
Jefferson Market from Sixth Avenue, south of 8th Street.
August 20, 1927.
P.L.Sperr, Photographer.

(2)
Jefferson Market Sixth Avenue and 8th Street.
April 6, 1928.
P.L.Sperr, Photographer.

Greenwich Avenue, east side, north from Christopher Street to 30 Greenwich Avenue north of 10th Street, showing old Jefferson Market and the old jail. Subway construction is going on underneath Greenwich Avenue.

August 20, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Sixth Ave., at the convergence of Greenwich Ave. (foreground) and Christopher Street on the west side of same, viewing eastward to show the Eighth Street station of the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line. Buildings shown across same are on the east side of the Ave. from 8th (right) to 9th (left) Streets. Note in the left foreground the foundation work for the new Womens Detention Prison (former site of the old Jefferson Market).

December 31, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
A northward view on the east side of Sixth Ave., from West 8th Street.

May 1, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
Similar to No. 1, but viewed northeastward on Christopher Street. On the extreme left is Greenwich Ave., and a corner of the new Women's Prison.

September 8, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

Sixth Avenue at N.W. corner of Greenwich Avenue, showing bed of Minetta Creek and site of old Jefferson Market. December 31, 1929.

(2)
The same from Greenwich Avenue and viewing northward. Demolition in the foreground is for the new Detention House for Women.
1929.

1929.

Jefferson Market Courthouse and tower, seen from Greenwich Avenue, east side, between Christopher and 10th Streets.
December 31, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Sixth Ave., north from Greenwich Ave. On the left, appears the new Detention House for Women; Formerly the site of Jefferson Market.

October 13, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
A view of the newly completed building, which replaced the old landmark that stood here for years. Shown is the Greenwich Ave., side.

October 13, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same; from the street level. Note the Christmas Trees for sale in the foreground.

December 24, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Sixth Ave., at the S.W. corner of Greenwich ave., as viewed from the 8th Street station of the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line, showing the automobile parking space, occupying that area. Also shown (left) are the rears of 3-story houses, facing on Gay Street, and bearing Nos. 13 to 19 (left to right). Adjoining same, and northward, is a 7-story warehouse (H, Behlen & Co.), facing on and bearing Nos. 12-10 Christopher Street. No. 8 Christopher Street, is the Pirates Den. Prominently shown (left to right) are the 12-story Heptagon Building (Nos. 147-153 Waverly Place), and a 17-story apartment house (No. 45 Christopher Street), between Waverly Place and Seventh Ave. South.

October 3, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(2 & 3)
A set of 2 views showing the same location at an earlier date and prior to clearance.

October 11, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

Sixth Ave., west side, south from, but not including Greenwich Ave., showing the St. Joseph's R.C. Church, at the N.W. corner of Washington Place, and The Waverly, a 16-story apartment house, at the S.W. corner of Waverly Place. Also shown, (in the background), is a 12-story apartment house, at the S.W. corner of Cornelia Street, and a portion of the 8th Street Station of the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line (in foreground).

P. L. Sperr.

October 3, 1931.

29 West 8th Street, and west, to Sixth Avenue, a close-up of the dry cleaners, restaurants, tea shops, art shops, and beauty parlors which make up this important Village thoroughfare. H. Behlen & Brothers, beyond the Sixth Avenue elevated, are in a building on the south side of Christopher Street. May 24, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

Southeast on northeast side of Greenwich Avenue from 12th Street to its southeastern terminus at Sixth Avenue.
March 16, 1933.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

(1) Sixth Ave., west side, south from West 8th Street, as seen thru clearance on the east side. Also shown is a portion of the 8th Street Station of the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line.

June 5, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same; a limited view, to and including Waverly Place.

June 5, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) Sixth Ave., west side, south from West 8th Street, as seen thru clearance on the east side. Also shown is a portion of the 8th Street Station of the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line.

June 5, 1935.

(2) The same; a limited view, to and including Waverly Place.

June 5, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.
Jefferson Market Court House. About 1935. 6th Ave. & Greenwich Ave. at Christopher and W. 9th St.

(1) 63-59 West 8th Street, at, adjoining and east of the N.E. corner of Sixth Ave., as seen thru excavation at the S.E. corner.

June 5, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, from a different angle.

June 5, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

P. L. Sperr.

West 8th Street, at, adjoining and east of the N.E. corner of Sixth Ave. Excavation partially shown on the right, is at the S.E. corner of Sixth Ave.

June 5, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

West 8th Street, east from Sixth Ave., showing W.P.A. employees re-moving surface car tracks.

November 23, 1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

(1)
8th Street (formerly also known as Clinton Place), south side, west from 24 West 8th Street to Sixth Avenue. This is one of the principal shop and restaurant sections of Greenwich Village. Between 30 and 34 West 8th Street is the upper end of Macdougal Street. In the background is the Sixth Avenue Elevated Station. 28 West 8th Street, occupied by the Jumble Shop Restaurant, has in its time housed various notable people. James Fraser, the sculptor, lived here; and the buffalo nickel was designed here by his wife, Laura Fraser. Edwin Arlington Robinson wrote some of his poetry at this address.
May 24, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, west from No. 20. Note the demolition at the S.W. corner of MacDougal Street. "Gonfarone's," a famous restaurant occupied this site for years. For further data upon same, see the New York Times of May 30, 1937.

June 1, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

Greenwich Avenue, northwest from West 9th, 10th, and Charles Street's respectively, showing a progressive view of the W. P. A. track removal project on this thoroughfare. In the distant background is the vague outline of the massive New York Port Authority Building at 111 Eighth Avenue.

June 23, 1937
No's 1-2-3

W. P. A. photo
FIVE BOROUGHS PROJECT

title: Sixth Avenue - 8th Street, east side - looking south

text:
Sixth Avenue, east side, north from between W. 8th and 9th Streets. The open area in the foreground is formed by the meeting of the aforementioned thoroughfares and Christopher Street and Greenwich Avenue. This is to be identified as "Village Square". View 3 shows the W. 8th Street station that was formerly located here. Intersection in the left foreground is W. 9th Street and the bank is at the N. E. corner thereof.

March 8, 1939
March 10, 1939
January 17, 1939

P. L. Sperr
